Visit SAP Mobile Experience Community Page and click ‚Äúfollow‚Äù to get the latest development and innovation of our solutions. We look forward to hearing about your experience with setting up the solution in your landscape; please do share your thoughts and comments below. Enter here for additional questions regarding SAP Mobile Experience Applications.

entry.title: What‚Äôs New in SAP Build Q2 2025 - Release Highlights
entry.content:
Q2 brought a wave of innovations to SAP Build, including improvements across governance, integration and user experience. We also had several announcements in the spotlight at SAP Sapphire 2025 around new AI capabilities, unified pricing, and of course Joule Studio, which lets you create custom Joule skills and AI agents. In case you missed it, check out our roundup of key updates from SAP Sapphire and the announcement of Joule Studio.

If you‚Äôre interested in shaping the future of SAP Build, we‚Äôve introduced the SAP Build Discovery Initiative 2025. We‚Äôre looking for participants to meet with product teams, test early prototypes and bring your perspective to influence innovations from day one. Find more info here.

Now let‚Äôs dive into the Top 10 release innovations from Q2 2025!

Enhanced governance capabilities

1. Empowering business users to maintain rules through an application

In Process Automation projects, business users are often the content owners of decisions and the logic behind business rules. While the SAP Build Lobby is a powerful environment, it can also be challenging to navigate and maintain the content of separate artifacts. 

Now IT and dev teams can give business users access to decisions via a purpose-built application, which is opened in SAP Build Work Zone. By empowering business users to access the logic this way, it helps mitigate risks of unauthorized changes, while also reducing delays around the change management process.

Manage decisions through a purpose-built application

2. Improved governance with approval flows & multi-node project transport

Strong governance frameworks are essential to ensure that your development activities remain secure and compliant. We have now released two features that support greater control and quality assurance:

  • Governance approval flows: This enables administrators to control who is authorized to create or transport projects across tenants or sub-accounts. The approval process is fully customizable, allowing organizations to implement quality gates aligned with their specific governance and compliance requirements.
  • Multi-node project transport: Approvers can now move SAP Build projects (apps, processes, automations) through a controlled Dev -> Test -> Production landscape, with approval steps and quality checks at each stage. This ensures dev teams are moving projects securely and efficiently across tenants.

Governance approval flows

Seamless interoperability and AI-powered integration

3. Importing Business Process Model & Notation (BPMN) to generate process artifacts automatically 

Great news for our automation enthusiasts ‚Äì it‚Äôs now possible to import BPMN processes from other tools into SAP Build! BPMN is the industry standard for defining workflows, decisions, and interactions across systems and teams. 

Now process designers can migrate existing BPMN processes from SAP Signavio, SAP NetWeaver, and IBM to generate process artifacts automatically. This long-awaited transportability helps to speed up the logic creation significantly, as well as acting as the bridge between SAP Build and other process modeling tools. 

To get started with BPMN process imports, see the Help Portal.Import BPMN processes into SAP Build

4. Improved SAP SuccessFactors integration with event discovery

From the SAP Build Lobby, developers can manage and connect SAP and non-SAP systems through the Unified Customer Landscape (UCL). Now in the UCL, developers can discover business events from SAP Cloud Application Event Hub, as well as SAP SuccessFactors solutions. This improved integration supports more relevant scenarios for HR processes, such as employee onboarding and compensation management. 

5. AI grounding in company-specific content for tailored responses

This feature makes it possible to base Joule copilot and other embedded AI capabilities on up-to-date documents and user-created content in SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition through the RAG (retrieval augmented generation) method. Rather than giving generic responses, it provides end users with more accurate and domain-specific content.

AI grounding within Joule copilot

6. Joule-based assistant to easily migrate SAP HANA applications to CAP

For simplified innovation across services, the SAP HANA Application Migration Assistant is a new extension available in SAP Build Code. This automates the conversion of XS classic applications into CAP-based services to accelerate modernization and help businesses adopt cloud-native architectures faster.

For more info, see Product Updates for SAP Build Code ‚Äì June 2025 Edition

Optimized user experience and accessibility across devices

7. SAP Mobile Start as the unified mobile access point for users

SAP Mobile Start addresses the challenge of fragmented access to enterprise applications and information for mobile users. The connection of SAP Mobile Start with SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition ensures that users have consistent and secure access to business applications, tasks, and notifications, regardless of their location or device.

 8. Preview SAPUI5 updates for better UX management

To address the need for more controlled testing, we‚Äôve introduced the ability to preview upcoming SAPUI5 versions in non-productive environments within SAP Build Work Zone. Admins can activate the preview in a staging or dev tenant, validate compatibility and confirm everything works as expected before go-live ‚Äì ensuring agile development, reduced downtime, and better user experience management.

For more info, read the blog post.

SAPUI5 version preview in SAP Build Work Zone

9. Local Entry Point (LEP) to simplify access to standalone sites

The new Local Entry Point (LEP) concept of SAP Build Work Zone simplifies how SaaS application providers integrate business solutions into SAP BTP. Providers can generate a standalone entry-point site in the consumer‚Äôs subaccount, eliminating the extra efforts and complexity required to set up their own instances.

To get started, see the Help Portal.

10. Updates to Mobile Development Kit for enhanced UI, APIs and more

The latest release to SAP Mobile Development Kit (MDK) has brought several new updates for customers, including the newest version of Mobile Services Client in the Google Play Store and Apple App Store. Among the newest enhancements to UI is support for donut charts, providing a new way to visualize data and emphasize different aspects of datasets.

See all the latest updates: What‚Äôs New in Mobile Development Kit client 25.6

Ready to see these in action?

To learn more and see live demos of the latest release highlights, watch the replay of What‚Äôs New in SAP Build Q2 2025 Webinar:

entry.title: SAP UX Q3/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start
entry.content:
This series of posts gives an overview of user experience innovations in the cloud from the last six months, covering our whole portfolio, such as AI and Joule, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, SAP SuccessFactors, as well as covering  innovations in our UI technologies for building great UX.

In this first post, we‚Äôll look at the latest cross-suite UX innovations, coming from Joule, SAP Work Zone and SAP Mobile Start.

Here are the links to the other posts in the series published so far:

  • Part 2: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and SAP Fiori Launchpad (generally available innovations).
  • Part 3: Beta AI Innovations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.
  • Part 4: SAP SuccessFactors (AI, Joule and More).
  • Part 5: SAP Ariba and SAP Fieldglass.
  • Part 6: SAP Customer Experience and SAP Concur.
  • Part 7: UI Design and Technology for Web and Mobile.

Before we get started: if you haven‚Äôt already seen them, do have a look at the overview of public cloud UX innovations I posted in Q1/2025 (parts 2 to 7 are linked in part 1):

  • SAP User Experience Q1/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 1: Many New Innovations Available (AI, Joule and More).

This upcoming series of posts includes Joule and AI UX highlights from individual products within the SAP Business Suite, but for a more comprehensive overview of our recent AI innovations, not just UX related, have a look at:

  • SAP Business AI: Release Highlights Q2 2025.
  • SAP Sapphire Innovation Guide ‚Äì SAP Business AI.

 

Joule User Experience Innovations

Joule is the AI-powered copilot for SAP systems, offering a powerful new user experience, using natural language to access our cloud products and providing a seamless flow for the user wherever they are, on desktop, laptop or mobile devices.

First, we‚Äôll have a look at the latest generic or cross-product UX innovations, before I give you some pointers to the product-specific innovations as well as news about developing custom capabilities.

Cross-Product Joule UX Innovations

This section covers these user experience innovations:

  • Joule Analytical Pattern.
  • Joule supports multiple conversations.
  • Use Joule in 11 languages.
  • Joule stand-alone: Joule for Consultants
  • Joule in Microsoft 365 Copilot and Microsoft Teams
  • Joule Agents.

Joule Analytical Pattern

This new pattern is available in all products which give users access to our Joule copilot. This new pattern is powered by SAP Analytics Cloud, with data from models that are indexed by the Just Ask feature of SAP Analytics Cloud.

Figure 1: Example Joule Analytical Pattern. Alt Text: an animated GIF showing how a user asks Joule ‚ÄúShow me sales commission by agend for model bike sales‚Äù, and how Joule shows a horizontal bar chart for top 5 sales commissions per sales agent.

As you can see in figure 1, users can now access analytical insights from the product they are working in, without having to first navigate to SAP Analytics Cloud, making work more efficient and hence also more enjoyable.

The example in figure 1 is what we call a descriptive question, but Joule can respond to a wide range of queries:

  • Descriptive questions, such as ‚ÄúWhat is the total revenue for Q1?‚Äù or ‚ÄúShow me sales by region in 2025‚Äù.
  • Comparative analysis, such as ‚ÄúCompare sales between 2023 and 2024" Or How do profits in Germany compare to France?‚Äù
  • Time series analysis, such as ‚ÄúShow me sales by month‚Äù or ‚ÄúShow the trend of customer acquisitions over the last 6 months‚Äù.
  • Top / Bottom N analysis, such as ‚ÄúShow me top 5 sales by store‚Äù or ‚ÄúList the bottom 3 regions in terms of sales‚Äù.

Find out more in this blog post:

  • Introducing Analytical Insights in Joule: Empowering Smarter Decisions, Instantly.

With the introduction of this new pattern, Joule now supports four interaction patterns:

  1. Informational pattern, for querying written documents, such as SAP documentation in the SAP Help Portal, or customer policies etc.
  2. Navigational pattern, for finding and navigating to applications.
  3. Transactional pattern, for interacting directly with business applications.
  4. Analytical pattern, for answering analytical queries directly in Joule.

Joule Supports Multiple Conversations

When having a conversation with Joule, you can ask follow-up questions, building on the previous questions and answers in the conversation, since Joule keeps the context.

Now you can initiate up to ten conversations in parallel, with Joule keeping the context for each of the conversations, so that when you return to a previous conversation you can continue where you left off. Figure 2 shows what this looks like.

 

Figure 2: Joule supports multiple conversations. On the left, a conversation was started by asking ‚ÄúHow many languages does Joule support‚Äù. On the right, you see how active and expired conversations are shown. Alt Text: On the left, Joule replies with ‚ÄúJoule currently supports eleven language officially‚Äù and then lists them, below the answer a link to the source document ‚ÄúJoule Multi Language Support‚Äù is provided. On the right, the conversation history sidebar is visible on the left, overlaying half the screen, with a button ‚Äú+ New Conversation‚Äù at the top, followed by a section ‚ÄúActive‚Äù with two conversations and a sectin ‚ÄúExpired‚Äù with four. The bottom contains a link to ‚ÄúSettings‚Äù and on to ‚ÄúAI Notice‚Äù.

You can return to conversations within 8 hours. To start a new conversation, simply click on ‚ÄúNew Conversation‚Äù. The old conversation will be listed in the ‚ÄúActive‚Äù section, as you can see in Figure 2. The title of the conversation is automatically created by Joule using AI; users can rename the titles when they return to the conversation.  Joule supports a maximum of 10 active conversations.

After 8 hours, the conversation expires but is not deleted. It is kept read-only in the ‚ÄúExpired‚Äù section, as shown in Figure 2. Conversations are finally deleted 7 days after the creation date.

In the browser, Joule can be expanded to fill the screen, as shown in Figure 3.

Figure 3: Joule expanded to full-screen mode, showing the conversation history sidebar and the chat side by side. Alt Text: The same information is shown as on both screens of Figure 2, since the conversation history sidebar does not overlay the chat, and the chat is shown on the right with much more screen width.

Find out more in the documentation:

  • Using the Joule Web Client.

Use Joule in 11 Languages

Figure 3 shows that you can ask Joule which languages it supports, and it will answer with the list of 11 languages. Here they are in alphabetical order, with the variant of the language in brackets.

  • Chinese (Simplified)
  • English (US)
  • French (France)
  • German (Germany)
  • Greek
  • Japanese
  • Korean
  • Polish
  • Portugese (Brazil)
  • Spanish (Spain)
  • Vietnamese

Joule Stand-alone ‚Äì Joule for Consultants

In addition to providing Joule embedded in our products, we have a design pattern called Joule stand-alone, which we use for Joule for Consultants. With this pattern, Joule can be started directly, without first opening an SAP product and then opening Joule via the icon in the shell header. Joule stand-alone is opened in full screen, as shown in Figure 4.

Figure 4: Joule for Consultants using the Joule stand-alone pattern. Alt-Text: Joule full-screen, with one active conversation ‚ÄúCan you explaine about SAP Clean Core‚Äù, followed by a comprehensive answer, and scrolling options for reading the entire text‚Äù.

By supporting this pattern, people can open up Joule for Consultants directly and start asking questions about implementing or extending SAP products. Since in this case Joule is stand-alone, as the name suggests, the conversations you have there are not visible in the Joule instance that is embedded in our products, and vice-versa.

Joule in Microsoft 365 Copilot and Microsoft Teams

How often have you been in a chat with a colleague and needed to find some information from an SAP system? Up until now this would involve you leaving the chat, going to a different window and navigating to the right SAP application to get what were looking for.

Now, you can chat directly with Joule in Microsoft Teams, use Joule in Microsoft Teams and Microsoft Teams Mobile as an app, and ask Joule questions directly in Microsoft 365 Copilot. To get an idea of how powerful this is, watch this video:

To get started, have a look at the documentation:

  • Integrating Joule with Microsoft 365 Copilot

Joule Agents

We are bringing SAP Business AI to the next level via Joule Agents, that can autonomously plan and execute multi-step workflows.

Why do I include this in a section on user experience updates? Aren‚Äôt Joule Agents a back-end thing? Well‚Ä¶ the reason is simple: Joule Agents significantly enhance the overall user experience, as opposed to the user interface, because the system will do a lot more for you based on your requests. This means that the overall experience you have using SAP goes up a level, since you can get a lot done much more easily than before.

Joule Agents can be triggered from Joule directly, or embedded within applications. These four marketing videos show you examples of agents available today:

  • Finance: Dispute Resolution Agent (1:38 minutes)
  • Procurement: Sourcing Agent (1:48 minutes)
  • Sales and services: Account Planning Agent (1:24 minutes)
  • Human Resources: Performance and Goals Agent (1:34 minutes)

This example for customer service agents goes into more detail:

  • CX Agents (in SAP Discovery Center).

For a general overview of Joule Agents, have a look here:

  • Joule Agents on sap.com.
  • AI Agents in Action (blog post).
  • Envision the Future of Generative AI with SAP's AI Agents (blog post).
  • How SAP‚Äôs AI Agent Architecture Enables Unprecedented Automation and Decision Augmentation (blog post by Philipp Herzig).

Product-specific capabilities

In addition to the above generic capabilities, our products provide a large number of Joule skills for getting your work done more efficiently, as well as a handful of the new agents discussed above. For a comprehensive overview of Joule capabilities, including product-specific skills available today, here‚Äôs where to go:

  • Joule Capabilities (a 484 page (!) PDF document from July 11th, 2025, including a list of What‚Äôs New)
  • Joule Capabilities (online documentation)

Customer-specific Joule skills

You can now build your own Joule skills using Joule Studio, which has now been made generally available. Read Michael Ameling‚Äôs overview blog post:

  • Joule Studio is generally available in SAP Build: Empower your business with intelligent automation

Joule on Mobile Devices ‚Äì now for SAP SuccessFactors too

Joule has been available via SAP Mobile Start since Q1/2025 (as announced in this blog post), and is now also available directly from within the SAP SuccessFactors mobile app, supporting these three patterns:

  • Transactional: Joule can handle tasks like requesting time off, updating contact information, and even deleting phone numbers, directly within the chat interface.
  • Navigational: Joule can guide users to specific pages within the app based on their requests, such as directing them to where they can assign team goals.
  • Informational: Joule can access documentation and knowledge bases to answer questions about company policies, HR guidelines, and other relevant information, providing summaries and links to related resources.

Figure 5 shows two examples of the transactional pattern plus one example of the informational pattern (‚ÄúCan I use my private car for my business trip?‚Äù).

 

Figure 5: Examples of Joule on the SuccessFactors Mobile App. Alt Text: The image shows three examples: The first shows the response to the request by a manager ‚ÄúView time off approval‚Äù, with the details of one request, including the employee's name, the time-off period, and the type of time-off (vacation). The user can view the details, approve, or decline the request. The second screen shows a conversation where the user asks if they can use their private car for a business trip, and the system responds that they can, providing details on the reimbursement policy. The third screen shows the user requesting one day of vacation leave on March 3, 2025. The system confirms the request and provides the details of the leave, including the start and end times, and the date the user will return to work.

Find out more here:

  • Say Hi to Joule in SAP SuccessFactors Mobile, Powered by SAP Build - Part 1: Unlocking AI for HR)
  • Joule in SAP SuccessFactors Mobile: Getting Things Done with AI...
  • Documentation: Joule Available in SAP SuccessFactors Mobile - May 2025

Further information on Joule

If you want an overview of what‚Äôs new, or want to set up Joule in your landscape, have a look at the documentation:

  • Joule documentation (including What‚Äôs New, What is Joule?, integration guide)
  • What is Joule? PDF file

For an overview of what is planned, have a look at the road map for Joule in the SAP Road Map Explorer:

  • Joule Road Map.

 

SAP Build Work Zone

SAP Build Work Zone users and administrators benefit from these recent innovations:

  • New Side navigation for SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition.
  • SAPUI5 version preview.
  • Mobile Start supports Work Zone, advanced edition.

New Side Navigation

As I announced in April, in my blog post Upcoming Design Updates for the SAP Business Suite (SAP Fiori for Web), we are introducing some design updates to all our products in the SAP Business Suite to further increase consistency, helping users to feel confident and at ease when using a suite of products ‚Äì no unexpected surprises. One of these is the introduction of a navigation menu on the left side of the screen.

SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition, is the first product to support this new design. Figure 6 shows what it looks like when the navigation menu is expanded, while Figure 7 shows it collapsed.

Figure 6: Side navigation expanded for SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition. Alt Text: A screen showing a SAP Build Work Zone screen with a navigation menu on the left with four entries ‚ÄúCentral Procurement‚Äù, ‚ÄúGlobal Support‚Äù, ‚ÄúMy IT Experience‚Äù (selected), and ‚ÄúSelf Services‚Äù. On the right various cards are shown in a section ‚ÄúEmployee Information‚Äù.

 

Figure 7: Side navigation collapsed for SAP Work Zone, standard edition. Alt Text: similar to Figure 6, but with the navigation menu on the left collapsed to the width of an icon, with four icons shown representing the four navigation options.

SAPUI5 Version Preview

We have introduced a new feature that allows administrators to preview upcoming SAPUI5 versions in non-productive environments within SAP Build Work Zone, two weeks before they are adopted in the productive environment.  Until now, the latest SAPUI5 versions were automatically adopted in production environments, which limited opportunities for early evaluation ahead of deployment.

By enabling the preview setting on specific non-productive sites, administrators can assess compatibility and performance with the upcoming version. This controlled testing environment helps identify and address potential issues, reducing the likelihood of disruptions in production. After the two-week preview period, the RTC version becomes the default, aligning all sites with the latest stable release.

When looking at the sites in the site directory, those sites for which the preview is switched on are indicated clearly, as shown in Figure X.

As with the standard edition, your native and web apps are available within the Apps Screen of SAP Mobile Start, as well as in your Favorites Section on the Start Screen, based on your individual selection. 

Tasks and Notifications from SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition, are also integrated into SAP Mobile Start: they are shown next to your business tasks and situations in the To-Do sections and in the Notification Center. Figure 9 shows an example with notifications from the advanced edition.

This integration is automatically available to customers with SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition or SAP SuccessFactors Work Zone if the SAP Mobile Start toggle is enabled in the Site Manager.

Figure 9: SAP Mobile Start notification center with notifications from SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition. Beyond providing Joule natively for mobile devices, SAP Mobile Start has recently introduced a number of user experience improvements with their 2.2 and 2.3 releases. In addition to supporting SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition, as described above, the main new features are:

entry.title: New in SAP Mobile Start V2.4: Integrate and Launch SAP Document AI on Mobile
entry.content:
With the SAP Mobile Start‚ÄØ2.4 release, users can leverage SAP Document‚ÄØAI‚Äîintegrated seamlessly within the Mobile Start app‚Äîto transform document handling into a secure, intelligent, and automated experience. They can scan or upload documents directly from SAP Mobile Start, which are then processed by the SAP Document AI service. This streamlines processing, cuts down manual work, and boosts data accuracy throughout your operations. In this blog, I'll walk you through the integration steps, prerequisites, and configuration details needed to bring SAP Document AI capabilities to your mobile users. 

Preconditions 

Before you begin, ensure the following prerequisites are fulfilled. 

Subscribe to SAP Document AI

Ensure that your SAP BTP subaccount is subscribed to the Document Information Extraction service (document-information-extraction-application-ias with embedded_edition instance). Once complete, access the SAP Document AI workspace from your BTP subscriptions to configure document types and schemas relevant to your business scenarios. For more information, refer to the official user guide. 

Enable Identity Authentication for SAP Build Work Zone

In SAP Build Work Zone, navigate to Site Manager > Settings, and ensure Identity Authentication is enabled. 

Screenshot: Enabling Identity Authentication in SAP Build Work Zone Settings

Note: Valid only for SAP Build Work Zone subscription made before 20 March 2025.

Configure Trust Relationship for API Access

To allow SAP Build Work Zone to consume SAP Document AI APIs, you need to add a dependency in the SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS) administration console: 

  • Go to the Applications tab 
  • Select the SAP Build Work Zone application 
  • Under Dependencies, add a new entry with: 
  • Name: documentai (or any unique name) 
  • Application: Select the ‚ÄúSAP Document AI‚Äù entry in your IAS tenant 

Create Destination for SAP Mobile Start

To authorize SAP Mobile Start App to access SAP Document AI, create a destination in your BTP subaccount with the following settings: 

  • Name: sapdocumentaimobilestartintegration 
  • Type: HTTP 
  • Authentication: NoAuthentication 
  • Proxy Type: Internet 
  • URL: (Use https://<your-tenant-url-endpoint>/document-ai/v1, located in Document AI instance > service key > endpoints > backend > URL) 

Add the following additional properties: 

  • HTML5.DynamicDestination = true
  • HTML5.IASDependencyName = documentai (dependency name created in SAP Cloud Identity Services) 

Once completed, both‚ÄØSAP Build Work Zone‚ÄØand‚ÄØSAP Mobile Start‚ÄØare authorized to access SAP Document AI. You can control user access in SAP Document AI using default authorization policies via Identity Authentication service. (Learn more)

Configuring tile for SAP Document AI access in mobile 

To make SAP Document AI accessible via SAP Mobile Start: 

Step 1: Create a New App in Site Manager  

In SAP Build Work Zone, navigate to Site Manager > Content Manager and create a new App. 

  • URL: https://<your-tenant-url>/launchpad?sap-ushell-config=headerless#InboundDocument-manageInDocumentAI
    ‚ÑπÔ∏è Use sap-ushell-config=headerless to hide the launchpad header
Step 2: Configure Navigation Parameters 

In the Navigation tab, add the following parameters: 

  • name: Schema name - Optional (from SAP Document AI workspace > Schemas tab) 
  • latest: true, this signifies that only the latest version of the schema is used 
  • client_ID: Client ID (from SAP Document AI workspace > Settings), preset to ‚Äòdefault‚Äô 
  • instance_ID: Instance ID (from SAP Document AI workspace > Settings or BTP account > Instances > Select SAP Document AI instance) 
  • showWorkspaceHeader: true 
Step 3: Configure Visualization 

You can set your own preferred title, subtitle, icon. 

  • Visualisation Type: Static Tile 
  • Add the following name-value parameters:  
  • mobilestart.type: documentAi 
  • mobilestart.documentAi.clientId: (as specified in Navigation Tab parameters) 
  • mobilestart.documentAi.instanceId: (as specified in Navigation Tab parameters) 
  • mobilestart.documentAi.documentSchemaId: Optional - needed if only a specific schema scenario should be enabled, otherwise all active schemas will be shown to the end user. You can find Schema ID in SAP Document AI workspace > Schemas tab 

Screenshot: SAP Document AI Tile Visualization in SAP Build Work Zone

You‚Äôve now created a fully functional SAP Document AI tile for SAP Mobile Start! üöÄ 

User Experience in SAP Mobile Start 

As a business user, you can locate the newly created SAP Document AI tile in the SAP Mobile Start app using the Search function. For easier access, you can also add the tile to your Favorites. When you tap the tile, you‚Äôll be directed to a native document selection screen. Depending on how the service was configured by the administrator, you may have the option to select a document type and schema. If the tile is configured for a specific schema use case, it will be automatically selected. 

Screenshot: SAP Document AI tile in SAP Mobile Start App 

Upload Options 

  1. Scan via Camera ‚Äì Leverages the device‚Äôs native camera with real-time preview, cropping, rotation, and filtering. Multiple scans are compiled into a single PDF. 
  2. Select Images from Gallery ‚Äì Users choose previously captured images which are compiled into a single PDF. 
  3. Select File from File Explorer ‚Äì Users upload a single PDF from their device‚Äôs file system. 

 Screenshot: Scanning a document via device‚Äôs native camera  

Upload Validation & Handling 

Before uploading a document, the app performs several validation checks to ensure compatibility. The file size must not exceed 50 MB, and the document should contain no more than 100 pages. Additionally, file names are automatically sanitized to remove any invalid characters. Once these checks are successfully passed, the upload process begins, with a visible progress bar indicating status. Android users can upload multiple documents synchronously.  

After the upload is complete, the document extraction workflow is triggered, and users receive a success notification confirming the process. 

Track Status and Review Document 

To monitor the progress of document extraction, simply open the Document Overview from the overflow menu within the document selection screen. This action launches the mobile-optimized SAP Document AI UI, providing a clear and intuitive view of the status, allowing reviews and other updates related to your uploaded documents. 

Screenshot: Track status and review document via mobile optimized UI 

Conclusion 

With the release of SAP Mobile Start 2.4 and the seamless integration of SAP Document AI, business users now benefit from a truly mobile-first, intelligent document processing experience. Whether it's capturing receipts on the go, processing invoices, or extracting data from complex forms, SAP Document AI empowers users to automate workflows efficiently‚Äîright from their mobile devices. This integration brings the power of AI-driven document handling directly to your fingertips, enabling smarter, faster, and more scalable business operations.

entry.title: SAP Mobile Start V2.4: SAP Document AI integration and much more. Release Update
entry.content:
With the recently released version 2.4, SAP Mobile Start has provided a lot of new features, like integrating with SAP Document AI, onboarding via deep links and the support of additional text (sensitive content) in native push notifications. 
Let¬¥s have a joint look at those new features. 

With the integration with SAP Document AI, users can scan or upload documents directly from SAP Mobile Start, which are then processed by the SAP Document AI service. So, if you for instance need to scan and upload a quality certificate, you can start the upload process right from SAP Mobile Start, and the SAP Document AI service takes care of all needed follow-up steps, like extracting the data and assigning it to the right business objects.  

 
Screenshots: SMS with SAP Document AI
 
For further information and a detailed step by step guide on how to setup SAP Document AI service within SAP Mobile Start, please have a look at my colleague Umair¬¥s blog: New in SAP Mobile Start V2.4: Integrate and Launch SAP Document AI on Mobile. 
 
In my last blog, I introduced the site switch. Since our last release, SAP Mobile Start remembers your previous site connections, including multiple different sites and you can easily switch between sites by signing out and then selecting the respective site from the site menu. Now, with version 2.4, you can do this directly from the app profile and settings menu, which makes the process even simpler.
 
 Screenshot: Site switch in Profile screen. 
 
So far, SAP Mobile Start has supported two comfortable ways to onboard users. First, users can onboard by scanning a QR code from the SAP Build Work Zone or SAP Start web page. Second, users can get onboarded automatically via a managed configuration if an Mobile Device Management system is in place. Now, users can also be onboarded via deep link.
How does this work? IT teams can invite users to onboard to SAP Mobile Start via an email or message and provide a deep-link that users can use to initiate the onboarding process, after they have installed the app. After tapping on the link, SAP Mobile Start opens and the user can directly onboard to the respective SAP Build Work Zone/ SAP Start system. You can find further details in our documentation.
 
With version 2.4 we have also introduced Top News ‚Äì news that is so important to users, that it is shown prominently on the Start Screen. As for the regular news, this feature can also easily be added via the SAP Build Work Zone Site Manager.Regular news are still supported as well. Please check our documentation for details. 

Screenshot: Top News
 
Until now, only public text was visible in push notifications, which often resulted in generic messages lacking sufficient context for the user. With the 2.4 release, SAP Mobile Start can now load and display additional details directly in the push notification, providing more meaningful and informative messages. This enhancement is controlled by a feature flag in the Mobile Services Admin Cockpit. For further information, please see our documentation on notifications and on how to access the cockpit. 
 
Screenshot: Additional details in push notifications
 
I hope you will enjoy these new features in SAP Mobile Start.

entry.title: Unlocking SAP Fiori and other business content on Mobile: A Practical Guide
entry.content:
Introduction: Accessing SAP business content on mobile

While analysing the recent search queries from users around ‚Äúthe use of SAP on mobile‚Äù we came across the below examples.

  • is there an app for SAP Fiori? 
  • can I access SAP Fiori from mobile? 
  • how to use SAP Fiori on iPhone? 
  • can SAP be used in mobile? 
  • how to open SAP on mobile? 
  • what SAP business content is available on mobile?

There were also questions around how SAP Mobile Start fit into the picture with the standard set of mobile apps for each of the cloud solutions from SAP; for e.g. SAP SuccessFactors mobile.

Providing clarity on these kinds of questions served as the motivation for writing this blog. We will also look at the broader set of business content that can be accessed from mobile as standard or via configuration.

Is SAP Fiori Client still relevant?

The SAP Fiori Client mobile app provided a native runtime environment for SAP Fiori apps on iOS and Android devices.  It was removed from the Apple App Store and Google Play Store on March 31st, 2022. (Refer to SAP Note 2992772).

While the above SAP note does recommend the users of SAP Fiori to transition to SAP Mobile Start, the above search queries gave the impression that customers probably could do with bit more guidance on the overall strategy and approach around accessing SAP business content including SAP Fiori apps from mobile.

Decision tree for alternatives to SAP Fiori Client

As mentioned in the SAP Note 2992772, one of the options is for the users of SAP Fiori Client to transition to SAP Mobile Start. Here‚Äôs a visual representation of the decision tree for customers who are still using SAP Fiori Client as covered in SAP Fiori Client successor recommendations.

Product positioning of SAP Mobile Start

SAP Mobile Start is positioned as the mobile native entry point for business applications, processes and business data from SAP and non-SAP solutions. SAP Mobile Start was initially released for iOS (iPhone and iPad) in September 2021 and the Android version was later released in June 2022. This also signified a change in mobile strategy for SAP by moving away from the hybrid world to native app approach.

 

The mobile app for SAP's central entry point solutions

SAP Mobile Start brings the content that is deployed on SAP‚Äôs central entry point solutions to mobile users.

 

Once the business content is deployed on these solutions, you can enable the power of mobile to the end-users with a QR code scan at almost no additional implementation effort or deploy using Mobile Device Management (MDM).

 

Accessing SAP business content from mobile

Now let‚Äôs dive deeper into how the following types of business content can be deployed and consumed via SAP Mobile Start.

  1. standard business content from SAP S/4HANA that is mobile enabled
  2. custom SAP Fiori apps created using SAP Build
  3. custom native apps created using SAP mobile services
  4. other SAP business solutions content

1. SAP S/4HANA standard business content on mobile

Let‚Äôs address the question on how to access SAP S/4HANA business content (SAP Fiori roles and apps) via mobile.

  • SAP Fiori Apps Reference library can provide a list of SAP Fiori apps that are optimized for mobile phone and tablet. For e.g. you can discover apps ‚Äúby Line of Business‚Äù; for e.g. Finance, Sourcing and Procurement etc.

 
  • You need to implement SAP Fiori roles and apps for your chosen processes on your SAP Fiori launchpad on SAP S/4HANA; refer to How to Deliver a Great User Experience with SAP S/4HANA.
  • You can then federate and bring the business content (SAP Fiori roles and apps) to one of the central entry point solutions mentioned above. Refer to the learning journey: Setting up SAP Mobile Start with SAP S/4HANA on SAP Build Work Zone which explains how to do this using SAP Build Work Zone and bring it to mobile.

You can also refer to below assets:

  • SAP Fiori Deployment Options and System Landscape Recommendations is the reference document for all consultants, partners and customers who implement SAP Fiori. Do note that it also mentions the use of SAP Build Work Zone as a central entry point deployment option.
  • SAP Fiori Deployment in 2025: Embedded vs. Work Zone Standard vs. Advanced Edition also gives some insights into comparing various deployment options.

2. Creating and consuming custom SAP Fiori apps

SAP Build is a unified application development and process automation solution, enabling personalization and efficiency at scale. You can create custom SAP Fiori apps, using SAP Build Apps (for low-code development) and SAP Build Code (for pro-code development). You can connect to your SAP S/4HANA or other backend system, use visual tools to define data models and UI elements, and leverage generative AI with tools like Joule to accelerate development.

SAP Build Work Zone can act as the central entry point to consume these custom apps as well as the federated (standard) business content from SAP S/4HANA. SAP Mobile Start can consume the content that is deployed on SAP Build Work Zone.

3. Creating custom mobile apps that follows SAP Fiori guidelines

Some customers may have use cases for which they might want to create custom native mobile applications that meets the following requirements:

  • utilize the native capabilities offered by the respective operating systems
  • while also following the SAP Fiori design guidelines
  • and maintaining the same user-experience as that of the business solutions from SAP.

This is where SAP Mobile Services comes into picture. It is an open standard based service on SAP Business Technology Platform that enables simple mobile application development, configuration, and management. It offers:

  • SAP Mobile Development kit which is a metadata driven tool that can allow you to develop cross platform applications.
  • Or SAP BTP SDKs for iOS as well as Android for those who want more flexibility beyond what the above metadata driven approach can provide.

These SDKs follow SAP Fiori design guidelines to preserve the familiarity of both the native operating system experience as well the SAP Fiori app experience; refer to SAP Fiori mobile design guidelines.

Any custom native app that you create can of course be launched from SAP Mobile Start via a native tile; refer to add native apps to your content.

4. Other SAP business solutions content

To be a true native entry point, SAP Mobile Start app also needs to bring the business content and key capabilities from other SAP business solutions to a mobile user.  Let's have a closer look at the possibilities.

  • SAP S/4HANA (as explained above)
    • mobile enabled apps from SAP S/4HANA SAP Fiori launchpad via content federation 
    • workflow notifications and situations
  • SAP Task Center integration for tasks; for e.g. Purchase Order approval from SAP S/4HANA. Also tasks from SAP Ariba , SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Cloud for Customer, SAP Concur, SAP Fieldglass, SAP Field Service Management, SAP Marketing Cloud, SAP Workflow Service, 3rd party providers
  • UI integration cards displaying Insights and custom cards
  • URL tile to Cloud solutions from SAP e.g. SAP Concur web
  • Analytical story from SAP Analytics Cloud
  • Native app tile to launch specialised app from the respective SAP Cloud solution
    • e.g. SAP Concur mobile
    • or deep links where SAP Cloud solution supports the same; e.g. using SAP SuccessFactors deep link to directly launch Compensation details
  • SAP Document AI integration

 

Big picture on SAP‚Äôs mobile portfolio

To complete the picture on SAP‚Äôs mobile portfolio, we must also talk about the dedicated mobile apps that comes with each of the cloud solutions from SAP ; for e.g. SAP SuccessFactors mobile, SAP Analytics Cloud mobile, SAP Concur mobile etc and how SAP Mobile Start fits into the picture.

SAP Mobile Start in the context of other SAP mobile apps

SAP Mobile Start is not intended to provide the ability for the end users to access all mobile enabled capabilities from all the cloud solutions from SAP. It is meant to be a native entry point from where the following can be done.

  • the most valuable capabilities and content from the business solutions can be accessed as described above.
  • and the specialised mobile apps provided by each of these cloud solutions from SAP can be launched.

 

Conclusion:

In summary

  • SAP Mobile Start is the mobile native entry point into SAP universe for a mobile user.
  • Administrators can deploy the most critical content from various business solutions from SAP as outlined above on SAP's central entry point solutions and bring them to SAP Mobile Start.
  • The end-users can further use the specialised standard SAP mobile apps.
  • SAP Mobile Services provides a choice of SAP BTP SDKs that can be used to create custom native apps when end-user needs go beyond the standard set of apps provided by SAP while also maintaining the familiarity of the respective operating system as well as SAP Fiori design guidelines.
  • The users of SAP Fiori Client are encouraged to move to SAP Mobile Start.

We look forward to hearing your experience with setting up these solutions in your landscape. We are keen to hear about mobile personas and use-cases you have taken advantage of. Please do share your thoughts and comments below.

Stay up to date with latest news and post your questions or feedback about SAP Mobile Start in the Q&A area. Start by visiting your SAP Mobile Experience community page and click ‚Äúfollow‚Äù. We‚Äôll be publishing more informative blog posts.

entry.title: Introducing SAP Fiori for Android/iOS 25.8: Innovative Enhancements for Android and iOS
entry.content:
SAP Fiori continues to advance its technological offerings with the release of SAP BTP SDK version 25.8, featuring exciting updates for both Android and iOS. This release introduces a suite of new capabilities as well as upgrades to current features, enhancing user experiences on business apps.

New in SAP Fiori for Android 25.8

In the following section, we‚Äôll give you a brief overview about everything that‚Äôs new in SAP Fiori for Android 25.8.

Circular In-Place Progress Indicator

The circular in-place progress indicator displays the status of ongoing processes when loading is initiated by a button. An indicator within the button shows the loading state. The progress indicator has been enhanced to allow customization of the icon button so that once loading is finished, the icon button can be changed to a different icon.

For more information, check out the Circular Progress Indicator article in the SAP Fiori for Android design guidelines.

Object cell with a circular progress indicator

Illustrated Message

The illustrated message component, which helps communicate empty, error, and success states through a combination of engaging illustrations, solution-oriented messages, and a conversational tone, has been updated with new illustration assets.

To learn more about this component, refer to Illustrated Message.

Illustrated message with the new ‚Äúempty task‚Äù illustration

Native File Viewer

The native file viewer, which allows users to preview files, now supports viewing password-protected PDFs by prompting them to enter a password in a dialog before the file is displayed, expanding accessibility and document control within apps.

For more information, check out Native File Viewer.

Password-protected PDF files in native file viewer

Picker Form Cell

The picker form cell, used for making date and time-based selections, is now available for Jetpack Compose.

See Date and Time Picker Form Cell for more information.

Date picker form cell with Horizon tonal color option

Stepper Form Cell

The stepper form cell and the nested stepper control, which allow users to incrementally increase or decrease a select value, are now available for Jetpack Compose.

Check out the Stepper Form Cell guideline article to learn more.

Stepper form cell in horizontal layout (top) and vertical layout (bottom)

Text Input Form Cell

Text input form cells have been enhanced to provide currency support, allowing users to enter currency values in single property form cells.  The form cells now feature ISO codes  that automatically format the text input with the corresponding currency symbol.

For more information, refer to Text Inputs.

‚ÄÉ

New in SAP Fiori for iOS 25.8

Check out what's new in SAP Fiori for Android 25.8. 

Illustrated Message

Just like the Android equivalent, the illustrated message component has been updated with new illustration assets to help communicate empty, error, and success states with engaging illustrations.

Learn more about this component in the Illustrated Message SAP Fiori for iOS guideline article.

Illustrated message in different containers

Modals and Sheets

We have added new guideline articles for modality and sheets that cover all types of modals and sheets, including but not limited to full-screen modals, non-modal sheets, action sheets, popovers, and form sheets.

For more information, refer to Modality and Sheets.

Modal sheet‚ÄÉ

Pickers

The date range picker is now supported as a picker form cell, enabling the triggering of the date range selection component.

Take a look at the Pickers guideline article for more information.‚ÄÉ

Date range picker

Text Inputs

Text inputs now come with currency support via a new view modifier, enabling display of the ISO code in the text input label, showing the currency symbol after editing, and applying localized formatting using native Apple APIs and formatters.

Check out Text Inputs to view more details.

Text input - single property form cell with currency field support

 

Resources

Design Guidelines

A detailed documentation on component anatomy, behavior, and interactions allows you to use components that match your use case. Crosslinks to Google‚Äôs Material Design Guidelines for Android and Apple‚Äôs Human Interface Guidelines for iOS, as well as links to development documentation, help you navigate to these resources. Additionally, you can find a feedback function on each guideline article that allows you to provide feedback.

SAP Fiori for Android Design Guidelines | SAP Fiori for iOS Design Guidelines

UI Kits for Figma

SAP Fiori for Android and iOS UIKit

With the updated SAP Fiori for Android and iOS Design Kits, it‚Äôs now easier than ever to use the latest components and patterns in your mobile design. By using the Design Kits, you can quickly create a consistent user experience that enables app implementations at scale.

SAP Fiori for Android 25.8 UI Kits | SAP Fiori for iOS 25.8 UI Kits

‚ÄÉ

entry.title: SAP User Experience Update: What‚Äôs New for SAP S/4HANA 2025 (Private Cloud and On-Premise)
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA 2025 comes with a whole host of user experience innovations and improvements.  Web access via My Home and the SAP Fiori launchpad has many useful improvements, as does SAP Mobile Start for mobile access. Joule gives conversational access to Private Cloud Edition using natural language, now also with analytical insights. There are additional collaboration capabilities, and many improvements in details: some towards providing a more consistent and integrated SAP Business Suite, some simply making a user‚Äôs life easier. Finally, design and UI technology is also advancing, with powerful AI support for developers now available.

This post covers:

  • UX Updates for Consistent and Integrated Business Suite
  • Web access: My Home and SAP Fiori launchpad
  • Mobile access: SAP Mobile Start
  • Joule
  • Situation Handling news
  • AI-Assisted capabilities: outlook
  • New collaboration capabilities
  • UX improvements in details
  • UI adaptation improvements for key users
  • Design and Technology news

If you want to get an impression of how good SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, looks across all the main product areas, have a look at the online Product Tour.

Since this post covers what‚Äôs new, building on the previous 2023 release, you might want to have a look at the UX innovations which came with the Feature Pack Stacks 00, 01 and 02 of the 2023 release:

  • SAP User Experience Update: What‚Äôs New for SAP S/4HANA 2023 (Private Cloud and On-Premise).
  • User Experience Advances with SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS01 (Private Cloud and On-Premise).
  • SAP User Experience Q4/2024 News for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2023.

For a full overview of what‚Äôs new since the FPS00 shipment of the 2023 release, have a look at the documentation (note that it includes features from the above 2023 FPS01 and FPS02 blog posts, as well as this one):

  • What‚Äôs New for SAP Fiori launchpad for SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

 

UX Updates for Consistent and Integrated Business Suite

We aim to provide a consistent and integrated experience for all users of the SAP Business Suite, which means providing an entry point for users to access all the various SAP products within the suite, and ensuring that the user experience across these products is consistent, making it easy for users to use applications from different products.

Entry Points

Figure 1 shows our approach for providing a web and a native mobile entry point to the products of the suite, such as SAP S/4HANA Cloud. I‚Äôd like to highlight that Joule can also be seen as an entry point to access the entire suite, since our goal is to provide Joule wherever you are, be it in our web applications or native mobile apps. Using Joule, our goal is to allow users to query and perform actions on all the products and applications which they are authorized to use, simply using natural language. As you‚Äôll see below, we are making good progress towards this goal.

Figure 1: Entry points providing an integrated workplace for accessing the SAP Business Suite. Alt Text: Image showing Joule on the left, ‚Äúavailable web and mobile‚Äù, and on the right a diagram with boxes indicating that SAP Mobile Start, SAP Start, and SAP Build Work Zone provide central access to SAP, with three boxes below for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, SAP SuccessFactors and Other SAP Products.

Web Central Access

I have covered recent UX innovations in our web central entry points, such as SAP Start and SAP Build Work Zone, and central services such as SAP Task Center, in my recent cloud UX blog posts. Since these capabilities also apply to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition as well as SAP S/4HANA (except for SAP Start), I will not repeat them here, but rather refer you to them:

  • SAP User Experience Q1/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 1: Many New Innovations Available (AI, Joule and More).
  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

 What we will look at in this post in detail are UX innovations for local access from web or mobile, via My Home and the SAP Fiori launchpad, and via SAP Mobile Start. Each has a dedicated section further below.

Design Updates for Suite Consistency

To achieve consistency across the suite, we have made design improvements which are relevant for a consistent user experience across the entire SAP Business Suite, and which are now available with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 and SAP S/4HANA 2025. As I mentioned in my April blog post Upcoming Design Updates for the SAP Business Suite (SAP Fiori for Web), consistency of the user experience across the various applications used by a user is an important part of overall usability, helping users to feel confident and at ease when using a suite of products ‚Äì no unexpected surprises.

In this section, we‚Äôll look at four design updates provided by the SAP Fiori launchpad, as well as examples of the new design for illustrations:

  • Navigation menu: Side navigation
  • Updated shell bar
  • Updated user menu
  • Updated notifications
  • New illustrations design

Navigation Menu: Side Navigation

Many SAP products already offer a navigation menu on the left of the screen, a pattern already familiar to many people. Hence, we have decided to apply that approach to navigation across the SAP Business Suite in upcoming releases.

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA, the side navigation is displayed as an overlay, as you can see in Figure 2. It gives you direct access to your favorite apps, either directly or via the folders you have created. It also gives you direct access to your Spaces and Pages. The previously available menu to access all your spaces and pages along with personalization options is available via the entry ‚ÄúAll Spaces‚Äù at the bottom of the menu.

A big benefit of this new navigation menu is that you can now access your favorite apps directly from any application. Previously, you would have to return to My Home and then click on your favorite app, now you can access it directly from the menu, as shown in Figure 2.

Figure 2: The new navigation menu, opened up from the new shell bar, showing direct access to Favourite Apps, My Spaces and All Spaces. Alt Text: an image showing a list of sales orders and on the left a pop-over with a navigation menu with the sections already mentioned. Below the ‚ÄúFavourite App‚Äù eight apps are listed as well as two folders for favorite apps, plus the folder ‚ÄúInsights‚Äù for the insight tiles.

New Shell Bar

The new shell bar design for the SAP Business Suite is available for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. The immediately visible difference is that now the product name is displayed to the right of the SAP Logo, in this case ‚ÄúS/4HANA Cloud‚Äù as you can see at the top of Figure 2. The logo and the name are all contained within a clickable area, which brings the user to the start page (e.g. My Home).

The new shell bar enables the next two design updates to the user menu and to notifications.

By default, after upgrading, the new shell bar is visible, with the new navigation menu. We advise that you check any test automation and RPA (Robotic Process Automation), since you may need to make some adjustments ‚Äì in particular if you log off at the end of a test.

Updated User Menu

The new user menu design shown in Figure 3 provides more space for the avatar of the user, and provides more space between items for easier selection. The settings are always at the top as the first entry, and the ‚ÄúSign Out‚Äù option is separated from the actual navigation options in the list, to make it easier to find.

 Figure 3: Updated design of user menu and notifications. Alt Text: On the left an image of the previous user menu and the updated user menu. On the right an image of the updated notifications list, showing four notifications in the group ‚ÄúLast Month‚Äù, each with a title, two lines of description and a line with the data and a ‚Äúmore‚Äù link.

Updated Notifications Design

The new simplified design of notifications shown on the right in Figure 3 fits better with the overall design of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA, and provides simpler interactions. By default notifications are sorted by date, with grouping by ‚ÄúToday‚Äù, ‚ÄúYesterday‚Äù, ‚ÄúLast Week‚Äù, ‚ÄúLast Month‚Äù. Users can also choose to sort by importance.

New Illustrations Design

We have modernized the design of our illustrations, and also made them easier to understand. Figure 4 shows two examples ‚Äì one for indicating that something went wrong (the fallen ice cream cone), one for search, with an example of where the search illustration is used when opening a list report application without any filter values defined.

 Figure 4: Examples of new illustrations. Alt Text: On the left top three different size illustrations showing an ice cream cone fallen on the ground; bottom left an illustration of a globe with a magnifying glass, representing ‚Äúsearch‚Äù. On the right an image of a list report showing the search illustration since no data has been selected.

 

Web Access: My Home and SAP Fiori Launchpad

The 2025 release brings a number of improvements in My Home, the start page in the SAP Fiori launchpad, as well as some improvements in the launchpad itself (beyond the design updates mentioned above) ‚Äì for users as well as for administrators.

My Home

Here is an overview of the enhancements with this release:

  • To-Dos:
    • Tasks: Enhanced workflow relevant information and in-place actions
    • Situations from both standard and extended framework- are displayed
  • Intelligent homepage experience to boost productivity (cloud only):
    • Intelligent app recommendations.
    • Intelligent generation of pre-delivered cards.
  • Improved user experience: 
    • Drag & drop is now enabled in the insights section, so you can directly rearrange your tiles and cards.
    • Information about deprecated apps: any such apps are marked with an ‚Äúdeprecated2 icon .
  • Manage News application.

 This collection of videos shows the individual features of My Home ‚Äì both new and already existing ones:

  • My Home - Deep Dive (video collection)

Figure 5: My Home in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 and SAP S/4HANA2025. Alt Text: A screenshot showing all the sections of My Home: To-Dos with tabs for Tasks (selected) and Situations;, a row with News on the left and Pages showing 8 pages on the right; Apps, with tabs for Favorites (selected ‚Äì showing 2 folders and 7 apps), Most Used, Recently Used, Recommended; Insight Tiles, showing 8 tiles; Insights Cards, showing 4 cards, 1 with a list and 3 with charts.

To-Dos Enhancements

The To-Dos task cards now offer action buttons, for example to approve or reject items. Often, this requires some key information about the item, for example the name of the product and the value for a purchase requisition. These details are now visualized directly in the task cards, as you can see in Figure 5, making the workflow more efficient.

To-Dos now also shows custom Situations, created using the extended Situation Handling framework, in addition to the standard situations delivered by SAP.

Intelligent Homepage Experience

Another useful new feature is AI recommendations for applications: as you can see in Figure 5 in the Apps section of My Home, a new tab Recommended has been introduced which uses AI to create a list of applications which are recommended to the user to add to their Favorites.

To help users get started with My Home, we provide intelligent generation of pre-delivered cards, so that when they first log on, the Insights Cards section is not blank, but rather has a number of pre-delivered cards relevant to the user‚Äôs role.

Manage News Application

I‚Äôm glad to announce that administrators can now easily create their own news to be displayed on My Home, using the new Manage News application. Figure 6 shows the start page of the application, listing news articles.

You can specify title, subtitle and main text, a background image, the start and end dates for publishing, as well as categorizing and targeting the news for specific groups of users. Also, you can mark a news article as being ‚ÄúCritical‚Äù, so that it is highlighted accordingly. You can see an example in Figure 5.

Figure 6: Manage News application. Alt Text: Screenshot of the Manage News application, showing a filter bar and a list of two news articles with their title, subtitle, footer text, criticality, status ‚Äúpublished‚Äù and publish start and end dates.

To get a better impression of how it works, watch this video:

  • Video: Manage News Application in My Home for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (2:00 min.)

You can find out more about these My Home innovations here:

  • My Home documentation.

SAP Fiori Launchpad

The launchpad provides more than just the spaces and pages for finding and starting apps: it provides the runtime shell in which all the applications run, and hence the updates mentioned above such as the new navigation, the new shell bar and user menu. It also controls navigation between apps, as well as settings such as which theme to apply. Here are some additional improvements with the 2025 release. 

Automatic high-contrast and dark-mode detection, also for custom themes

Users can define on their front-end device‚Äôs operating system whether applications should appear in a light mode or a dark mode, or a high-contrast mode. Now these settings are taken into account also for custom themes, in addition to SAP visual themes.

Technically this is done by the launchpad supporting theme sets, which is a group of themes of the same family with different flavors ‚Äì such as the Horizon theme, with a light and dark version along with high contrast black and high contrast white versions. Customers can create their own theme sets using the UI theme designer. Have a look at the documentation:

  • Managing Your Settings (see the setting Appearance).

Hiding empty pages and spaces

The apps which a user sees on a page on the SAP Fiori launchpad, and the pages which appear in a space, depend on a user‚Äôs authorizations. This can lead to a page being defined in such a way that certain users are not authorized to use any of the apps therein; similarly, a space can end up not having any pages available to a user. Now, if this happens, any such empty pages or spaces are hidden from the user, rather than being shown empty. Find out more here:

  • SAP Fiori launchpad: Hiding empty spaces and pages.

Improved About Dialog for Application Information

We have simplified the about screen, organizing it into separate tabs for Application, System and Environment information, so that there is a clear separation between the different types of information ‚Äì see it in action in Figure 7:

Figure 7: New About dialog. Alt Text: A short video showing the list view of the Manage Sales Orders ‚Äì Version 2 app. The user opens the user settings menu in the shell header bar, selects ‚Äúabout‚Äù, and a popover appears with the same design as the user settings, showing three separate tabs listed vertically on the left for ‚ÄúApplication‚Äù, ‚ÄúSystem‚Äù and ‚ÄúEnvironment‚Äù, with ‚ÄúApplication‚Äù the default. Application shows title and ID of the app, along with framework version; System shows the product, system and tenant name; Environment shows the client device type and user agent details.

Update for Administrators of SAP Fiori Launchpad

Redesign of Apps for Managing Spaces and Pages

Up until now, the apps ‚ÄúManage Launchpad Spaces‚Äù and ‚ÄúManage Launchpad Pages‚Äù distinguished between entries which could be edited within a given tenant and entries which could only be used as templates when creating new spaces or pages. The editable ones were listed in the tab ‚ÄúCustomer-Created‚Äù, the others in the tab ‚ÄúPredefined‚Äù.

Our customers gave us feedback that this was in fact confusing, because a page which was listed as ‚ÄúCustomer-Created‚Äù in a non-productive tenant and which was transferred to a productive tenant became ‚ÄúPredefined‚Äù there, i.e. it was not listed under ‚ÄúCustomer-Created‚Äù despite it being customer-created.

Now, the design has been changed, with two tabs for editable entities (spaces or pages) and non-editable ones. For example, in the app ‚ÄúManage Launchpad Pages‚Äù, the tabs are called ‚ÄúPages‚Äù and ‚ÄúPage Templates‚Äù, as shown in Figure 8. No matter what tenant you are in, you cannot change or edit page templates, you can only use them to create new pages. The same applies to spaces in the Manage Launchpad Spaces app.

Figure 8: The redesigned app Manage Launchpad Pages with Tabs for ‚ÄúPages‚Äù and ‚ÄúPage Templates‚Äù. Alt Text: image shows an extract of the app showing the two tabs.

Role-dependent Launchpad Configuration Parameters

We provide administrators a new option to apply launchpad settings role-based, so that different roles can have different settings being applied. This can be helpful if a specific group of users need different settings, for example if you want to gradually introduce Spaces and Pages, you no longer have to switch it on for all users. Find out more, and further examples, in the documentation:

  • Setting Parameters per Profile

 

Mobile Access: SAP Mobile Start

The recent innovations I would like to highlight here are directly relevant for users accessing SAP S/4HANA directly:

  • Personalization
  • News ‚Äì now with images and top news
  • Document AI
  • Joule for Mobile (covered in the section on Joule further below)

Personalizing SAP Mobile Start

For a good and satisfying user experience, being able to personalize the UI so that it fits with how you like to work is a key element. To this end, SAP Mobile Start has now introduced personalization of the start page, allowing you to rearrange the order of sections as well as hiding sections which you don‚Äôt need ‚Äì take a look at it in Figure 9.

Figure 9: SAP Mobile Start personalization of the start screen. Alt Text: Four mobile phone images. On the left the start page, with the sections Insights and News visible. Next, an image of the edit screen, with five sections listed: Latest To-Dos, Favorites, Insights, App Suggestions (deselected), News. Next, an image of the five sections, all selected, now with Favorites first and Latest To-Dos second. On the right, the start page with the sections Favorites at the top (containing flat cards for apps), below that Latest To-Dos (containing larger cards for ToDos, one shocing a purchase requisition with Total Amount $799.99).

News with Images and Top News

News can now include images. Furthermore, we have also introduced Top News ‚Äì news that is so important to users, that it is shown prominently on the Start Screen. You can see examples of top news with an image as well as regular news with images in Figure 10. For more information, check out the

  •  SAP Mobile Start Administration Guide (documentation).

Figure 10: News with images, including Top News. Alt Text: Two mobile phone images shown, on the left the start page with Top News at the top, with an article and an image; below that sections for Favorites and Latest To-Dos. On the right a list of five news articles with text on the left and an image on the right.

Document AI Integrated into SAP Mobile Start

With the integration with SAP Document AI, users can scan or upload documents directly from SAP Mobile Start, which are then processed by the SAP Document AI service. So, if you for instance need to scan and upload a quality certificate, you can start the upload process right from SAP Mobile Start, and the SAP Document AI service takes care of all needed follow-up steps, like extracting the data and assigning it to the right business objects.  

Figure 11: Screenshots of SAP Mobile Start with SAP Document AI. Alt Text: 3 mobile phone images: on the left the start screen, in the middle a screen Select Document Type, with choices Standard Delivery Note (selected) and Supplier or Procurement quality certificates, on the camera showing an document, with a Save button.

 Find further information and a detailed step by step guide on how to setup SAP Document AI service within SAP Mobile Start here:

  • New in SAP Mobile Start V2.4: Integrate and Launch SAP Document AI on Mobile. 

Further Innovations and Information on SAP Mobile Start

SAP Mobile Start has further innovations related to integrating with SAP Build Work Zone, such as supporting spaces and pages from its new site experience, supporting its declarative UI integration cards, or supporting integration with the advanced edition.

To find out more about all the recent innovations as well as what is planned in our road map, have a look at:

  • SAP Mobile Start V2.0 - Release Update
  • Joule on Mobile & Start Screen Personalization: SAP Mobile Start V2.1 - Release Update
  • Support of SAP Build Work Zone, advanced and much more: SAP Mobile Start V2.2 & 2.3 - Release Update.
  • SAP Mobile Start V2.4: SAP Document AI integration and much more. Release Update.
  • SAP Mobile Start Road Map.

 

Joule User Experience Innovations

Joule is the AI-powered copilot for SAP‚Äôs cloud products, offering a powerful new user experience, using natural language to access them and providing a nice flow for the user wherever they are, on desktop, laptop or mobile devices.

First, we‚Äôll have a look at the latest generic or cross-product UX innovations in the web and mobile, before I give you some pointers to the product-specific innovations as well as news about developing custom capabilities.

Cross-Product Joule UX Innovations

This section covers these user experience innovations:

  • Joule Analytical Pattern.
  • Joule supports multiple conversations.
  • Use Joule in 11 languages.
  • Joule in Microsoft 365 Copilot and Microsoft Teams
  • Customer specific skills and agents.

Joule Analytical Pattern

This new pattern is available in all products which give users access to our Joule copilot. This new pattern is powered by SAP Analytics Cloud, with data from models that are indexed by the Just Ask feature of SAP Analytics Cloud.

Figure 12: Example Joule Analytical Pattern. Alt Text: an animated GIF showing how a user asks Joule ‚ÄúShow me sales commission by agend for model bike sales‚Äù, and how Joule shows a horizontal bar chart for top 5 sales commissions per sales agent.

As you can see in figure 12, users can now access analytical insights from the product they are working in, without having to first navigate to SAP Analytics Cloud, making work more efficient and hence also more enjoyable.

The example in figure 12 is what we call a descriptive question, but Joule can respond to a wide range of queries:

  • Descriptive questions, such as ‚ÄúWhat is the total revenue for Q1?‚Äù or ‚ÄúShow me sales by region in 2025‚Äù.
  • Comparative analysis, such as ‚ÄúCompare sales between 2023 and 2024" Or How do profits in Germany compare to France?‚Äù
  • Time series analysis, such as ‚ÄúShow me sales by month‚Äù or ‚ÄúShow the trend of customer acquisitions over the last 6 months‚Äù.
  • Top / Bottom N analysis, such as ‚ÄúShow me top 5 sales by store‚Äù or ‚ÄúList the bottom 3 regions in terms of sales‚Äù.

Find out more in this blog post:

  • Introducing Analytical Insights in Joule: Empowering Smarter Decisions, Instantly.

With the introduction of this new pattern, Joule now supports four interaction patterns:

  1. Informational pattern, for querying written documents, such as SAP documentation in the SAP Help Portal, or customer policies etc.
  2. Navigational pattern, for finding and navigating to applications.
  3. Transactional pattern, for interacting directly with business applications.
  4. Analytical pattern, for answering analytical queries directly in Joule.

Joule Supports Multiple Conversations

When having a conversation with Joule, you can ask follow-up questions, building on the previous questions and answers in the conversation, since Joule keeps the context.

Now you can initiate up to ten conversations in parallel, with Joule keeping the context for each of the conversations, so that when you return to a previous conversation you can continue where you left off. Figure 13 shows what this looks like.

Figure 13: Joule supports multiple conversations. On the left, a conversation was started by asking ‚ÄúHow many languages does Joule support‚Äù. Improved performance for scrolling in grid tables

Our engineers have done some magic so that now scrolling is very fast in grid tables, which are the table type typically used for working with large volumes of data.

Why do I call it magic? Well, modern web-based UIs have the UI layer running in the browser, managing direct user interactions, and calling services in the backend to get and update data. However, if you are working with a list of say over 100,000 items, you would have to wait quite a long time when starting the application until all items have been loaded into the browser. Hence we only load a certain number to start with, such as 100. This however means that when a user scrolls beyond the 100 which have been loaded, additional data needs to be fetched from the backend, which slows down scrolling. Now, our engineers have found a way to minimize this effect to almost zero, so that you have fast scrolling all the time ‚Äì magic!

This is useful if a customer knows that, for a certain application, the number of entries will not exceed 2.000 for example.
